'''Project Cloud Gap: Demonstrated Destruction of Nuclear Weapons ''' was a program run by the [[United States Department of Defense]] and the [[Arms Control and Disarmament Agency]] from 1963 to 1967<ref name="Herken1992"/> (or 1969, according to other sources<ref name="fuller">{{cite book|last=Fuller|first=James|editor=Corey Hinderstein|title=Cultivating Confidence: Verification, Monitoring, and Enforcement for a World Free of Nuclear Weapons|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=AMuigF4mQk4C&pg=PA127|accessdate=24 November 2012|year=2010|publisher=Hoover Press|isbn=9780817912055|pages=123â€“60|chapter=Going to Zero: Verifying Nuclear Warhead Dismantlement}}</ref>) whose purpose was to "test the technical feasibility of potential arms control and disarmament measures".<ref name=fas>{{cite web|url=http://www.fas.org/nuke/guide/usa/cloudgap/index.html|title=Cloud Gap: Demonstrated Destruction of Nuclear Weapons|work=[[Federation of American Scientists]]|accessdate=24 November 2012}}</ref> Arms control agreements discussed between the United States and the Soviet Union would involve on-site inspections, and such techniques - which involved giant drilling rigs and helicopter overflights to detect secret underground testing -<ref name="Herken1992"/> were field-tested by Cloud Gap.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Sheldon|first=Robert|year=2004|title=Military Operations Research Society (MORS) Oral History Project Interview of Alfred Lieberman, FS|journal=Military Operations Research|publisher=[[Military Operations Research Society]]|volume=9|issue=1|url=http://www.mors.org/UserFiles/file/Oral%20Histories/Lieberman.pdf|accessdate=23 November 2012}}</ref> The program was abandoned after a helicopter crash during a mock inspection exercise killed several team members.<ref name="Herken1992">{{cite book|last=Herken|first=Gregg|title=Cardinal Choices: Presidential Science Advising from the Atomic Bomb to Sdi|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=0GXaUCdxOJoC&pg=PA305|accessdate=24 November 2012|year=1992|publisher=Stanford UP|isbn=9780804739665|page=305}}</ref>
Cloud Gap's aborted work culminated in ''Field Test 34'', "an extensive mock dismantlement exercise" which demonstrated two things: if any party to a treaty attempted to cheat, the risk of detection was significant, and the party that cooperated and allowed for on-site inspection would see "significant amounts of classified information be put at risk and invariably lost".<ref name="fuller"/>
